subject: RE: [junit] multiple assertions
msgSnippet: AHHH...ok ;) From the other posts, sounds like you ve got a handle on it now. We had to do something similar recently, but it was for the actual production
messageBody:
AHHH...ok ;)

From the other posts, sounds like you've got a handle
on it now.

We had to do something similar recently, but it was
for the actual production code...running through a
class with data and making a list of all the errors.

Getting the tests set up to test each 'checkpoint' was
a pain ;)


-Eric

--- "Hoepner, Josh (J.M.)" <jhoepner@...> wrote:
> I unserstand what you are saying completely. It is
> a requirement of our tests that they continue to run
> after the first assertion fails. We don't want
> fatal asserts in other words. We would like to
> capture the results of all the assertions. The
> current way JUnit functions is to fail out of the
> test at the first failed assertion. This
> contradicts the requirement of our tests. The
> junit3.7b.jar file available in the article Mike
> sent seems to solve our problem. Thanks for your
> advice though!
>
> Josh Hoepner
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Eric Heikkila [mailto:ericheikkila@...]
> Sent: Friday, February 22, 2002 4:32 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] multiple assertions
>
>
> Ok, I'm not quite understanding (or vice versa), so
> how about showing us some examples?
>
> Something like:
>
> public class theTest extends TestCase {
>
> private DataClass data;
> private String name;
> private String address;
> private String phoneNumber;
>
> public void setUp() {
>
> name = "Franks, Rick";
> address = "1313 MockingBird Lane";
> phoneNumber = "800-999-1234";
>
> data = new DataClass(name, address, phoneNumber);
> }
>
> public void testName() {
>
> data.address(null);
>
> assertNotNull("Name should not be null",
> data.name());
> assertEquals("Incorrect name: ", name,
> data.name());
>
> assertNull("Address may be null",
> data.address());
> }
>
> public void testAddress() {
>
> data.name(null);
>
> assertNotNull("Address should not be null",
> data.address());
> assertEquals("Incorrect address", address,
> data.address());
>
> assertTrue(!data.isOk());
>
> // based on some silly assumption about
> // 'data' being NOT OK if the address
> // is not null and the name is null.
> }
> }
>
>
> What is it you are trying to test?
> And how do you currently have the test written so
> that
> it does not do what you want it to do??
>
> -Eric
>
> --- "Hoepner, Josh (J.M.)" <jhoepner@...>
> wrote:
> > We are automating these JUnit tests for regression
> > testing. Some of the methods we are running
> require
> > checking multiple attributes for their proper
> value.
> > It becomes much more useful if we can identify
> what
> > attribute asserts fail and which pass.
> >
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Eric Heikkila
> [mailto:ericheikkila@...]
> > Sent: Friday, February 22, 2002 3:49 PM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: Re: [junit] multiple assertions
> >
> >
> > ?????
> >
> >
> > If one assert fails, the whole thing is invalid.
> > Fix what is broken, and run it again.
> > Everything should pass.
> >
> > If you are check to make sure something is false
> but
> > are using assertTrue, then just do
> assertTrue(value
> > ==
> > false).
> >
> > -Eric
> >
> >
> > --- "Hoepner, Josh (J.M.)" <jhoepner@...>
> > wrote:
> > > Hello all,
> > >
> > > I am fairly new to JUnit and I have come across
> a
> > > problem while writing test cases. I am in a
> > > situation where I require one test case to have
> > > multiple assertions. If one of these assertions
> > > fails, I still need the others to run. I'm sure
> > > someone else has tried something like this in
> the
> > > past, does anyone have any suggestions?
> > >
> > > Thanks,
> > >
> > > Josh Hoepner
> > > Great Lakes Technologies Group
> > >
> >
> >
